title: pm fresh lockdown 500000 beach hottest
story: Sunseekers ignored signs pleading: “Too busy  Head home!” and caused chaos as the heat hit .C.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoozy brawls broke out, coastal roads were gridlocked and sands strewn with litter.Bournemouth East MP Tobias Ellwood said police told him , visitors were in the area.Town hall chiefs called for extra cops and roadblocks to deal with covidiots.There were similar scenes at Brighton, Margate in Kent, Camber Sands in East Sussex, and Southend, Essex.Up to  sunbathers fought in front of families at Orcombe Point near Exmouth, Devon. Witnesses claim some were taking drugs.Some virus limits are due to be lted from July .But following the mayhem, Boris Johnson’s spokesman said: “The PM and the government scientic and medical advisers have stressed the great importance of the public continuing to adhere to social distancing advice.“If the rules don’t continue to be followed and the virus starts to spread exponentially again, we will look at having to reverse some of the easements we’ve put in place.”Chief medical officer Chris Whitty added: “Covid- has gone down due to the efforts of everyone but is still in circulation.“If we don’t follow the social-distancing guidance, then cases will rise again.”But Bournemouth’s beach was filled to capacity for a second day running by sunseekers.Council leader Vikki Slade fumed: “We are appalled at the scenes in the last - hours.“The irresponsible behaviour and actions of so many people is just shocking. Our services are stretched to the absolute hilt trying to keep everyone safe.“We have had no choice now but to declare a major incident and initiate an emergency response. Please do not come. We are not able to welcome you yet.”Furloughed workers battled through traffic to reach beaches.Many ditched cars, leading to a record  parking fines.Dorset Police increased beach patrols. Assistant Chief Constable Sam de Reya said: “We strongly advise the public to think twice before heading to the area.”Cops shut routes to Durdle Door and said: “Please do not venture to the coast today. All parking spaces near the beaches are full.“Remember: You aren’t stuck in traffic, you are the traffic.”Hundreds were stuck in a -mile jam outside Camber Sands. A local fumed: “Why did people think it would be any dferent going to the coast today.“Next week the stampede will be to the pub. Chill people, wait a few days for the hysteria to subside. The beach isn’t going anywhere anytime soon.”Health Secretary Matt Hancock tweeted: “We all want to be outside enjoying the glorious sunshine but please do it safely and stick to social distancing rules.”Tory Mr Ellwood said alcohol sales should be restricted in shops near Bournemouth beach.He added: “Going to the beach like this is selfish. Lives are being put in danger.“If there were a big event in London, police would call in help from other forces and that is what we need here.“The restrictions and rules are being flouted and we risk undoing all the good work and effort that we have put in for  weeks.”  Another  tons of litter was taken from the beach morning, following eight tons on Wednesday. Bournemouth West MP Conor Burns called for drivers to be fined and vehicles clampedseen on approach roads.Mr Burns said: “The pictures from the beach are obscene. Local authorities can only respond based on guidance from government.”Rich Harle tweeted: “What was Boris saying about being able to rely on the commonsense of the British public ”Resident Helena Sellers said: “This is making me so angry.“It’s not just the fact that adults simply refuse to do as they are asked, or the fact they know they can be risking other people’s lives, but the fact they bring along their children and put them at risk.”Another local raged: “Gotta wonder how many are on furlough but won’t go back to work as ‘It’s not safe’.“Yet they are all happy to go to a beach with thousands of other sweaty strangers.”Forecasters issued a Level  heat alert, one below a national emergency.England’s top temperature was .Cat Heathrow.Storms started in the South West, and up to in of rain could fall in an hour today. THERE’S a large banner on Bournemouth Pier thanking NHS staff for their hard work, while signs outside the kiosks bear stern instructions about two-metre social distancing.But today, they were like relics from a forgotten age.As I stood on the sand, the hot air was thick with marijuana smoke and music blasted from hundreds of Bluetooth speakers as thousands of revellers turned a midweek afternoon into a chaotic party.Delighted children ran into a sea already heaving with gangs of laughing lads.Girls took selfies and popped prosecco corks as they lay cheek by jowl with grannies on the hottest day of the year so far.There were West Country accents, Londoners, even the odd Northerner. Some were making six-hour round trips after seeing images of the beach yesterday and realising that “staying alert” seems to have a dferent meaning here.Approach roads were gridlocked from am and, once there, people left cars wherever they would fit.By pm, crowds were swarming from the high street as teens flirted on the sand, zipliners launched off the pier and distant jetskis roared.Long queues formed at ice cream kiosks as sweat-soaked staff tried to keep up in scenes unimaginable a few weeks ago.Self-employed brickie Richard James, , was among the many taking a day off to hit the beach.The dad of three, from Southampton, who was with six pals, said: “We’ve got loads of beers and a bottle of vodka and we’re going to have a few drinks in the sun then head back and watch the football.“It feels great to be out having a good time finally and I’m not too worried about the coronavirus.”Fish and chip chef Tom Gallagher, , from Bournemouth, said: “I’ve worked the last ten days straight and told my boss I needed to take today off so I could have a break.”Tom, carrying three £ pints of lager from a beer truck, added: “It’s nice to see things back to normal and people out enjoying themselves.”Furloughed Jenner Patrick, , who had travelled -plus miles from Ealing, West London, to soak up the sun with her -year-old daughter, said: “I was ­worried about the coronavirus to start with but I’m not too fussed now.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman two wombs twins
story: The -year-old, who already has two daughters, also found out she had two cervixes — and might even have to go through two labours.She said: “The twins could be identical. The condition itself is quite rare but they went on to tell me that it was a one in a million chance for me to conceive twins in each womb.”Kelly and boyfriend Joshua Boundy, , were given the news at her -week scan.She added: “With my second baby they said that I might have a bicornuate uterus, which means it’s not fully formed.“So when I went for this scan, I was really surprised to learn that I have two of them!“I just thought, ‘God, that’s a shock’. It makes you feel incredibly grateful that this has happened to you and you get to have two amazing babies.”Kelly’s first child Agyness, four, was born eight weeks premature, while Margot, three, was six weeks early.Doctors say their biggest concerns are the twins will be premature or that Kelly will go into two separate labours.She said: “The plan is to have them both by c-section, but my last two births have been so quick there’s a risk that might not be possible.“In all honesty, the whole thing is pretty crazy.”Tesco worker Kelly, of Braintree, Essex, added: “We do have twins in our family and my Nana was a triplet but you never think that it’s going to happen to you.I especially never thought I’d have identical twins in two separate wombs!”Professor Asma Khalil, an expert in obstetrics at St George’s Hospital in Tooting, South London, told The Sun: “Uterus didelphys is a congenital abnormality where there is a double uterus with two separate cervices and possibly a double vagina as well.“It is estimated to occur in one in , women. There are just a handful of recorded cases of women with uterus didelphys who gave birth to identical twins across the world — it is extremely rare.“It can cause problems. In one case one twin was delivered at  weeks and the other carried on until late in pregnancy.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theatres five point phase reopening coronavirus
story: Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden has outlined the conditions under which performances can start again. Socially distanced rehearsals are expected soon, followed by screened shows, then outdoor events.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive performances will eventually be allowed again, at first with limited audiences, before increasing capacity. But no dates have yet been given to the proposals.Football was allowed back after a similar phased , with non contact training allowed before full contact - with behind closed doors games now taking place.Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said: “I desperately want to raise the curtain on live performances in theatres and music venues as soon we can - they are the soul of our nation and a lynchpin of our world beating creative industries.“We know the challenges - theatres must be full to make money, and performers need to be safe on stage as they sing, dance and play instruments - but I am determined to ensure the performing arts do not stay closed longer than is absolutely necessary to protect public health.That’s why weve developed a five-stage roadmap to bring our choirs, orchestras and theatres back safely. We had a roadmap for elite sport, and weve succeeded in getting that back on.Whilst the challenges facing performing arts are numerous, we must have clear steps to follow and provide as much certainty and focus as we can.”He revealed that they will pilot indoor shows to find out the best way to make plays, musicals and shows safe in the covid world.The culture secretary added:  Right now, we are supporting musicians, dancers and actors to safely resume training, rehearsals and recorded performances without an audience where organisations wish to.“We will then progress with outdoor performances with an audience - and some outdoor events are beginning to be planned for later in the summer.“Alongside this we’ll do some pilots on indoor performances to identy the best mitigations to take.“Eventually, and only when it is safe to do so, we’ll reintroduce indoor performances with audiences.I know the public wants its theatres open, our brilliant performers want to go back to work, and we will do all we can to get them fully back up and running.“Our roadmap provides a clear pathway back.”Chairs of theatres and arts organisations have warned “tens of thousands of artistic careers” are at risk unless shows get back on stage and the government provides more support.The letter, signed by chairs of some of the UK’s largest theatres, warns the “performing arts are battling for survival at a time when theatre matters more than ever”. It added: “Our industry depends on the £. billion of annual ticket sales that has now disappeared, with disastrous effects on companies, employees and freelancers.Even with a -metre social distancing rule, we could only fill about % of our seats – not a financially viable option.”The letter adds: “Without immediate and substantial support, theatres and performing arts companies will inevitably close and tens of thousands of artistic careers will be cut short.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cbeebies vet advice post lockdown peaceful pets
story: But for pets that have enjoyed weeks of human company, ato being left home alone may prove more challenging.A whopping  per cent of dog owners say they have bonded more with their mutt during lockdown and are now worried it will experience separation anxiety when they go back to work.Vet Cat Henstridge – known to CBeebies fans as Cat the Vet – tells Laura Stott her advice to ensure the post-lockdown period is peaceful, not painful, for your paw-fect pets.Cats like being alone and won’t be fazed by you going back to work – they’ll probably be glad to see the back of you.But sociable dogs need to readjust slowly to having solo time again.Make an effort once or twice a day to leave them by themselves, initially while you are in a dferent room or the garden.Choose a time when they are relaxed or tired and encourage them into a favourite cosy spot or their bed.If they seem distressed, comfort them, then go away again. Gradually build up time spent apart.Animals have sensitive noses and using pet-specic cleaning products in the home can be helpful to reduce their anxiety.Making sure there are no harsh smells will lower tension levels and allows your pet to relax. .Keep cat litter trays clean, and for very attached pets, especially puppies, leaving something with your scent on, like a T-shirt or old towel, can be soothing.Playing gentle music at a low volume can help to distract from any unfamiliar noises that may worry them.There are even pet podcasts available.Pets who knew le before lockdown should slip back into previous family routines eventually.Cats are already more solitary creatures, and dogs should cope wellyou prepare them properly.However, puppies that have only ever known lockdown, or dogs that have become too used to your company, may find it more challenging.A good way to help them adjust is by pretending to go back to work. Put on office clothes or a school unorm and act out your pre-lockdown morning routines.Go through the motions of leaving for work. Pick up your car keys, settle your pet, then close the door and leave them, evenyou only go and sit in the garden or take a walk.You might feel silly, but this can be really helpful for your pet, especiallythey have only ever seen you in your “off-duty”, stay-home outfits.When you come back in it’s vital that you wait until your pet is calm before greeting them, whether that takes five minutes or five hours.Don’t join in OTT celebrations or encourage reunion “zoomies”, as long- term this can enhance anxious behaviour and increase stress levels.By taking things slowly your pet won’t find the transition back to post-lockdown le too dficult.However,furry friends don’t seem to be settling well and you encounter signs of anxiety, such as toilet issues, high heart rates, constant chewing or scratching, it’s worth seeking advice from a qualied animal behaviourist apbc.org.uk or your vet.A remote camera can give clues to situations you might not be aware of, such as noises, that could be troubling your pet in your absence.With everyone at home constantly during lockdown, our pets may have struggled to rest properly.Cats famously like to snooze but dogs also need up to  hours of sleep a day and may have found lockdown exhausting.Sometimes pets are actually anxious because our constant company means they are over-tired and over-stimulated and now can’t think straight.For all pets it is up to us to ensure they are not disturbed when they are taking time out.Cats are generally good at taking themselves off to cat nap so just leave them to rest, but dogs often need a bit more help to switch off.Don’t fuss over them while they catch some sleep and help children to understand that when their best friend is snoozing, they need to be left in peace.For dogs in particular, lockdown may have changed their exercise routines dramatically, with some getting more frequent or far longer walks than previously.Start to readjust this now, to correlate daily timetables with your regular routines ing.If you normally walk your dog at specic times of the day, such as before and after work, then resume going for walkies on this schedule.Oryou normally use a dog walker or have help from another person during the day, make the effort to introduce them now, especiallyyou have a pet who hasn’t met them yet.If you are one of the many new pet owners who got a puppy or kitten during lockdown you’ve had a lovely honeymoon period to bond with your new buddy.However, it also means it’s likely your pet has never spent any time home alone.Before leaving you new addition solo, you must do sufficient training to ensure your puppy or kitten understands that being separated from you is OK.With puppies, build up slowly to ensure they are happy and get used to the idea of being handled by other people and socialising with other dogs.You can stay with your pupthey are more confident with you around but don’t allow them to be clingy and always reward positive, confident behaviour.For cats, six months is the ideal age to start training with a cat flapyou plan to use one.Professional help with training is now permitted again under government rules and is strongly advised.A bored pet can be an anxious pet. If they are under-stimulated their minds wander and your home can suffer the consequences – so keep them busy.For dogs, toys stuffed with treats, or scattering snacks into their bed to hunt, will give them something to do.There are also tutorials online for making home-made games and toys.For cats, include circuits and teasers to prevent your furniture being damaged.Rotate dferent ones daily, so there is always something new for your pet to investigate and play with.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. The Prime Minister has given the go-ahead for pubs, restaurants and hotels to reopen as of next month - albeit with social distancing restrictions in place - while non-essential retail is already free to resume selling. It will be easier for pubs to change how they work It is a bit technical, but it is the change that makes all the other bits possible. The bill will change the way pubs ask local councils for permission on changing how they open. It will reduce the consultation period for applications for pavement licences to from  calendar days to  working days, and grant consent after  working daysthe council does not issue a decision And it lowers application fee for a pavement and street cafe licence to just £.  Get used to being outside With a hard limit on the number of people allowed to be inside a pub at any given time, you wonapost be propping up the bar anytime soon. But perhaps the most noticeable change youaposll see at your local under under proposals laid out in the Business and Planning Bill, is that outside seating will become the norm. And to make that easier any outside areas that a pub has control over, like a car park, will be allowed to turn into seating areas.  You can take a pint homeAs part of the plans unveiled on Thursday, licensed premises will be able to serve booze for punters to take away and consume where in efforts to stop drinkers crowding indoors. While some pubs did this before and may have relied on it to keep themselves afloat during the lockdown, more pubs than ever will sell drinks for you to take home or drink off-premises in a bid to keep people as distanced as possible. More drinking space on the pavement outside pubs As part of the bill, Ministers are hoping to change how pubs get permission to set up on the pavements outside their doors. title: two super earths found orbiting
story: NewsTwo super-Earths found orbiting bright red dwarf star just  light years awaySuper-Earths have been found orbiting a red dwarf star cool enough to possibly allow surface water on an orbiting planet. Scientists say it could become one of the most studied planetary systems in the Solar neighbourhoodShareCommentsByNilima MarshallJoseph WilkesReporter:,  JUN News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo super-Earths have been discovered orbiting one of the brightest red dwarf stars in the sky. About half as big as the Sun, GJ  is just  light years away. Red dwarfs like GJ  have low surface temperatures, which makes them less luminous and often hard to detect. But stars like these are cooler than the Sun, which means the habitable zone - the orbital band where temperatures are mild enough to allow liquid surface water on orbiting planets - is much closer to GJ  in comparison with the Earthaposs distance from the Sun. The new planets, called GJ b and GJ c, were found using a high-precision, planet-finding instrument on the European Southern Observatoryaposs .-metre telescope at La Silla in Chile. Both are believed to be super-Earths - planets which have a mass higher than Earth but substantially below those of local ice giants Uranus and Neptune. The discovery was made by an international team of astronomers, including researchers from the University of Hertfordshire, The Open University and Queen Mary University of London. The scientists used a technique known as Doppler wobble, which enabled them to find the planets by measuring their gravitational interaction with GJ . As a planet orbits, it causes its parent star to wobble by a tiny degree. Astronomers can see the signature of this effect in the light emitted by the star. The researchers believe both GJ b and GJ c lie close to the inner edge of habitable zone and may be too hot to maintain liquid water on their surfaces. They estimate the surface temperature of GJ c, which takes . days to circle its host star, to be around C. GJ b, meanwhile, is much closer to the star, with an orbital period of . days. But the researchers say GJ  is less active than other red dwarfs, so the newly discovered worlds may be spared from strong stellar winds - outflowing material from the star which can erode a planetaposs atmosphere. Hence, the team are keen to learn more about this super-Earth system. Dr John Barnes, an astrophysicist at the Open University and one of the authors on the study published in the journal Science, said: Close orbiting planets like these have a high chance of being tidally locked to their host star. This means that as the planet orbits its star, the same hemisphere always faces the star. For the planets orbiting GJ , half of the planets would be in perpetual daytime and the other half in perpetual night time. So, it could be much cooler on some parts of the planets than others. The researchers also detected an unconfirmed signal, raising hopes of a third planet with a more temperate orbit. But Dr Barnes is cautious about this finding, saying: If the signal is a planet, it would orbit every  days.

She praised the response of the private sector - as well as public services - to the coronavirus crisis and insisted the party under Keir Starmer wanted people to succeed.In an interview with the Mirror, she said Labour had to demonstrate to the public that it could deliver on the security so many people were craving. “We’ve got to be really clear, particularly at a time like now, that Labour is on people’s side,” she said. “We want people to succeed, we want to make sure people are protected as well, in a situation that has been so hard for so many. “They need to feel that Labour can deliver on that need for security that so many people are feeling right now.” She stressed she was prepared to take a tough decisions when colleagues asked to make spending commitments. “We need to make sure that the money that people pay in taxes is properly spent,” she said. “If you want to change people’s situation then you’ve got to demonstrate that you can actually deliver that. “If I don’t think something is a good idea, I’ll certainly say that.” But Ms Dodds, who only became an MP in , stood by some of Labour’s pre-election economic policies.  Asked whether she still supported her predecessor John McDonnell’s plan to raise taxes for the top % of earners, she admitted: “I certainly think we need to have a more progressive tax system. “We’ve just gone through a situation where so many people have made enormous sacrices. “After that kind of a situation we do need to make sure that those who are making a contribution are those with the broadest shoulders. “Some of those suggestions that have been swirling around about generalised tax increases should not be what Government should be aiming at.” She added: “We’ve seen lots of cuts to taxation for the very best off people and I think right now those who can make that bigger contribution, should do.”  The Oxford East MP also suggested Labour could increase corporation tax - saying cuts had “not delivered” the additional investment promised. Calling for a thorough review, she that most small businesses were more concerned about business rates. She suggested sticking to some elements of the controversial re-nationalistation pledge - saying it had become “increasingly evident” that the broadband system wasn’t working. “We don’t have that provision across the country at the level it needs to be. The Government really needs to get a grip on that.”Ms Dodds warned that Boris Johnson ’s Government was in danger of acting too late in its handling of the next stage of the crisis, which has claimed at least , lives and tipped the country towards recession.“If we look at other countries, we have been quite slow with the health response. I’m concerned that we might be too slow with the economic response as well,” she said. She called for the furlough job support scheme, which starts to wrap up from July, to be extended for targeted sectors including pubs and leisure that are unable to reopen fully. “We shouldn’t be having the same approach adopted across the economy... we are going to see additional waves of unemployment unfortunately so Government needs to change that.” she said. There should be more support for those who had already lost their jobs and a nationwide programme to create new ones, which would “not necessarily” cost more but should be aimed at those who need it most. In the interview in Stevenage town centre which she visited with Mr Starmer, Ms Dodds backed the Mirror’s ‘Shop for Britain’ campaign which urges people to support local businesses. “High streets are really critical to communities. You can feel a little bit of the buzz coming back here but where people can be shopping locally it makes such a dference because that means the value stays in our communities,” she said.Brexit trade deal “I’m concerned about no deal because lots of businesses have been through such a dficult period during this crisis. If they have yet another disruption at the end of the year that would be very dficult. The Government has promised it will get that deal so we’re saying please make sure you do, the success of British business depends on it. We need to see what comes out of their negotiations. If they don’t reach that agreement then obviously we’ll try to make sure we don’t end up in a situation where business is harmed further, where more jobs are lost. We accept that our policy around Brexit was not one that persuaded the country.” Black Lives Matter “We’ve seen so many dferent reviews which have shown there is inequality, there is discrimination, so many recommendations about what needs to change and yet what has actually changed  Very little. The Government has announced yet another review but we know what isn’t working. Let’s just get on and fix it. There are big inequalities in the health and economic impact of this crisis. We need to do something about that. People felt that honouring certain iniduals in the way a statue does was deeply offensive, particularlythat suggested some of the practices around slavery were acceptable. I can fully understand that concern. There’s been a long argument around Cecil Rhodes in my own city for a very long time. It’s very clear that there’s an overwhelming consensus in favour of Rhodes not being honoured in that way.” Women in politics “There seems to be a big gap when it comes to engagement in economic questions. Sometimes I’d be sitting in the Commons when we’re talking about financial matters, and it’s not like these issues don’t affect women. What’s critical to me is whether we have leadership that wants to hear from women and represent women - ultimately a leader who is a feminist and I know that Keir is. Social media can be a wonderful thing but because it’s easy to be anonymous the kind of abuse that women can get is really concerning. It really shouldn’t be a barrier to people becoming engaged.” Climate change “We’ve learnt during this crisis that there can be theoretical risks which suddenly affect us very deeply. With the climate crisis we know we’re having record-breaking temperatures with increased frequency. Just last year the heatwaves we had were associated with quite a large number of people dying. I’m an optimist, there’s lots we can do to reduce carbon in our economy which will create highly skilled jobs at the same time. We’ve had a frustrating situation with on-shore windfarms because regulation has been completely choked off by regulation. There has got to be substantial change in aviation but we’ve got to do it in a planned way. It’s so dficult to get around dferent parts of the UK.” The Tories “I’d never focus on inidual personalities but Rishi Sunak has a big challenge now because there’s a very critical question about how we have an exit strategy which works for the country. I‘m appalled by the fact that we’ve had  years where people’s living standards are constrained in the UK. So many people who are working are really struggling.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe emails had been flowing back and forth, and the meeting was potentially looking very positive. But, says Phyllis Taylor, the ­moment she walked into the room, ­everything suddenly changed. The -year-old ethical fashion company founder says: “I had an ­incident where I got an email from a well-known high street brand to come in for a meeting, but the energy changed the minute she saw me.” London-based Phyllis, who launched Ghanaian-influenced Sika Designs  years ago, adds: “It’s not clear from my name where I’m from. “But I felt like the minute I entered the room the energy changed, and it just went downhill from there.” The fashion industry has long had a problem with a lack of inclusion for black models and designers, and it is the same for stylists, photographers, writers and art directors. The appointment of Edward Enninful, the first black editor-in-chief at the helm of British Vogue in  was widely welcomed. Andyou’re talking make-up, Pat McGrath, a black Brit from Northampton of Jamaican heritage, is the world’s most in-demand and influential artist, as well as the founder of luxury cosmetic brand Pat McGrath Labs, worth a reported billion. Black designers including Princess Diana favourite Bruce Oldfield, Ozwald Boateng, the first black designer to open on London’s Savile Row, and the late Joe Casely-Hayford who dressed rock stars and prime ministers, have blazed trails in the UK since the s.  And a new crop of talented contemporary black British designers, among them Martine Rose, Grace Wales Bonner and Samuel Ross, is emerging. But the high cost of further education, and accusations that top fashion schools such as Central Saint Martins are elitist, may explain why there aren’t more.In the wake of the Black Lives Matter protests following the death of George Floyd at the hands of the police, the spotlight has been shone on the systemic racism that affects the lives of black people globally – and fashion has been caught in its glare. In an internal memo to Conde Nast staff, Dame Anna Wintour, American Vogue’s editor-in-chief, apologised to the company’s staff for not finding “enough ways to elevate and give space to black editors, writers, photographers, designers and other creators”. Arguments over cultural appropriation, earnings disparities and a lack of visibility in fashion magazines means being black and working in fashion means fighting for a seat at the table – or having to create your own. Jermaine R Robinson, a music stylist and image consultant from London, says: “I feel like at the moment there’s a huge focus for black brands. “I know a lot of people who want to invest in that but didn’t know what brands are out there.”  Jermaine, , who has worked with American designer Telfar Clemens and recently shared a list of  black designers on social media, adds: “I put a call out on Insta and got flooded with all dferent kinds of brands. I even found a black-led gothic brand.” On the fashion industry having a problem with racism, he says: “Tokenism is highly active. I feel like there is a glass ceiling to how far we can go, I know many black people who are super talented but they just haven’t been given the time of day.” Activewear designer Dami Howells launched DAMIHOWtwo years ago after seeing that there was very little representation of black women in fitness. She says: “I foundyou wanted to buy gym wear that was comfortable, that makes you look nice and motivated to go to the gym to do any type of workout, it wasn’t very stylish.” While she is getting great feedback from her customers about the quality of her products and the company’s customer service, getting exposure has been a challenge. She adds: “When you reach out to non-black influencers to partner with, you don’t get a response.  “We need more support because everyone is used to buying from the brands they already know and they trust.  “But at the same time it’s refreshing for the community to see themselves being represented in a way that hasn’t happened before.” Fashion lover Emma Mathurine, , often feels uninspired by the offerings on the high street, and unrepresented. Emma, an accountant who also designs carnival costumes for Bel Dyes Massays: “A lot of fashion does come from street culture, of ying ethnicities. If you look at London it’s that ersity that gives it colour but that’s not reflected in the mainstream. There’s a massive underrepresentation of people that look like me as a black Caribbean person.

title: coronavirus left lost words struggling
story: NewsCoronavirus has left us lost for words and struggling to make sense of where we areIn these unrelenting days, the poet Tony Walsh trusted to speak for Manchester in the hours after the Arena bomb attack, once again has given us a place to pauseShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  JUN NewsTony Walsh " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTony Walsh’s new poem The Sum of Us has Britain in tears. In these unrelenting days, the poet trusted to speak for Manchester in the hours after the Arena bomb attack, once again has given us a place to pause. Three years ago, the writer Jeanette Winterson said Walsh had found “words where there are no words” through his poem This Is the Place, which he read in Albert Square the day after the bombing. Liam Gallagher said it was “the best thing to come out of any Mancunian’s mouth, ever”.Now, in the time of coronavirus, we are lost for words once more, shattered and struggling to make sense of where we are. And Walsh does it again, finding the common thread of humanity in all our vastly dfering experiences.“Some of us are sewing scrubs and some are sowing seeds   Some are stitching fragments into plans   Some are holding Zoom meetings with babies on our knees   Some are holding only lonely hands.” Being Tony Walsh, this isn’t a ­sentimental place to rest. “So some of us are wealthy, healthy some of us are poor,” he writes. “Some of us will… buy a magic pill   But some of us know ‘some of us’ won’t cut it anymore  If some of us are sick, we all are ill.” Speaking to him on the phone at home in Manchester, where he is locked down with his we and mother-in-law, who has Alzheimer’s, Walsh is full of the same passion with which he told Manchester “Choose Love”. “We’ve pressed pause on the world,” he says, “we don’t just have to press play again.” Later, the former council officer and factory worker says: “We can’t carry on how we were. Austerity, inequality, this is part of how we’ve got where we are. UK, Brazil, USA – what’s the common thread between the worst affected countries  “Could it be the right-wing nature of those governments  Yet it’s the opposite ideas – community, socialism, working together, internationalism – that have got us through.” The third anniversary of the Arena bombing on May  has recently passed, taking away none of the pain for bereaved or survivors, or the conflicted sense Walsh feels of forever being associated with that horric moment. ‘Tony Walsh’ was trending across the globe on social media, as his city was still clearing up the broken glass and surgeons were operating. “Three years on, there’s not one day that goes by that it isn’t in front of me,” he says. “I get letters, emails every day about it. I took that responsibility very seriously. It weighed heavily on me. But I know what an absolute privilege it was to be there on the square that day. As a writer you are in the business of conveying truths and creating connections.”  His latest poem was a commission from New Writing North, which supports writing in the north of England. “It started from wordplay – some of us are doing this, some are doing that, that became the Sum of Us, collectively,” Walsh says. “It started from thank you, but it needed to be more. The understanding that as long as the virus exists in the world, we’ve all got it.” As the father of a  and a  year old, Walsh worries particularly about the future for young people. “It’s like when I was , working at the sausage factory after  months on the dole, and we used to greet each other with ‘are you working ’,” he says. “No one was working then. I fear we are heading back to those days.”  As Walsh says: “Everything I work in – theatre, events, conferences, education, all are closed down. All I’ve got left is the scribbling business.” The last few weeks have seen some extraordinary responses from poets. A video of Hollow by Vanessa Kisuule, the Bristol City Poet for -, about the toppling of the Edward Colston statue in Bristol as part of #BlackLivesMatter, has been shared over half a million times. When we have no words, it’s poetry that can speak for us – yet arts organisations are now the drowning ones, without enough le support systems to go around. Walsh has written movingly about this in his poem, Arts and Minds, which will shortly be released as a video. The terrorist attack on Manchester Arena, as Winterson wrote back then, was a public event “as well as a heart-breaking series of private losses”. So too are these times when, as our Britain Connects project has shown, we have no way of knowing what is happening inside the le of the person walking past us in the park.

Figures show , confirmed cases from May  to June  that were transferred to the call centre-based scheme – still missing its vital app – were not reached. Shadow Health Minister Justin Madders said the revelation raises “major concerns”.Prime Minister Boris Johnson had vowed a “world-beating” test and trace system would be in place by the beginning of this month.And Health Secretary Matt Hancock promised an app essential to the scheme would be in action by the middle of May. He said: “Those testing positive have a responsibility to help halt its transmission and protect those most at risk.” Mr Hancock has refused to put a date on when a working app will be available. He said on Wednesday: “The app is progressing and we will launch it when the time is right.”  The SAGE advisory group was urging an increase in test and trace using a call centre system similar to the one in place now as early as February. In a development on testing, six walk-in centres will be trialled in Newcastle, Rochdale, Leeds, Slough, and Brent and Newham in London. As the company prepares to open many of its sites, it is also preparing to make some major changes that are likely to last for some time. Plastic screens have been installed between tables at a branch in Muswell Hill, London. They aim to protect customers and staff, while allowing the business to restart with confidence. The glass separators have been installed also between chairs located next to each other as well as sofas, to ensure customers are not at risk. Boris Johnson has encouraged people to do their patriotic best for Britain and head to the pubs when they reopen on July . Tory MP Gareth Johnson said: Going to the pub is a great British institution and vitalwe want to get our economy back on track. Emergency services were called to Loch Lubnaig, near Callander, Scotland, at .pm on Wednesday but were unable to save the youngster. Michael Heeps was from High Valleyfield in Fe and his family have today paid touching tribute to the much-loved youngster. They said: He was a much loved son, brother, grandson, nephew and cousin x Dozens of tributes were posted on social media by heartbroken friends and family. Cousin Emma Fraser wrote: Hearts breaking. R. I. P to my little cousin. fly high wee man. Another friend wrote: Thinking of the family. How tragic. God bless wee man. In England, two men got into dficulty at a weir in Cookham, Berkshire. One man was pulled from the water and taken to hospital in a serious condition, while another remained missing. Sadly, after a  hour search, Thames Valley Police confirmed a body had been found. Officers were called Lulle Brook, between Odney Lane and Mill Lane, in Cookham,  Maidenhead  on Tuesday night around pm.They attended alongside fire crews from both Royal Berkshire and Buckinghamshire Fire and Rescue services, South Central Ambulance Service, and Berkshire Lowland Search and Rescue. Hero Connor Godfrey was fishing on the weir in Cookham, Berkshire, yesterday evening and described how playful shouts turned to panicked screaming as two men got into dficulty. The chef said kids had been jumping from the weir into the gushing water below all afternoon, as well as a group of men later in the day.

A study of , adults found ten per cent believed that going off to fight in conflicts was the Armed forcesapos only purpose. One in three were unaware the British military play a major part in tracking and thwarting terror attacks, while  per cent didnapost know they help to deal with the aftermath of floods. But  per cent would like to be better informed, while six in  believe itaposs important that theyaposre updated about what the armed forces are doing during peacetime. Simon Bucks, chief executive of BFBS, the forces charity and media organisation which commissioned the study as part of Armed Forces Week, said: The military does so much more than defence, as weaposve seen during the Covid- crisis in this country. We want to help make the public more aware of everything they do. Films and TV shows - even ones based on real le events - can give a sensationalised and distorted view of military le. Stories about their apospeacetimeapos work often go untold - which is why weaposll be featuring a lot of it during Armed Forces Week - from supporting the NHS during the pandemic to providing hurricane relief in the Caribbean. There are many dferent roles in the armed forces, to suit people with a range of skills and personalities. Some of the day-to-day community roles might come as a surprise. The research also found just under one in seven adults think that, when thereaposs not a war on, soldiersapos time is their own to spend however they like. And  per cent believe they use battle tanks to get around on a daily basis.  Despite this lack of understanding about the militaryaposs , eight in  believe the UK needs an armed force. More than three in  also think the armed forcesapos role in supporting the NHS during lockdown has increased public awareness of what the military does.This support has included helping to build Nightingale hospitals and other medical units, acting as ambulance drivers, driving oxygen tankers and staffing mobile coronavirus testing units. The Army even teamed up with eBay to help healthcare workers find and order free PPE amid the crisis.During lockdown, just over a tenth of those polled, via OnePoll, have seen military personnel helping out in their local area. despite health facilities being left out of the lockdown easing.Boris Johnson announced on Tuesday that pubs, hotels, restaurants and hairdressers can reopen from July , as long as social distancing is in place.But gyms, spas, beauty salons and swimming pools were not given the green light to start readmitting the public.However, Gymbox today said bosses are looking at letting its members visit the premises due to the #xClack of clarity from the Government#xD.The gym revealed the industry was led to believe they could welcome back customers on July  - at the same time as the hospitality sector - but are yet to be given an explanation as to why they cannot reopen, the firm said.Senior staff at Gymbox are also looking at partnerships with pubs not planning to reopen to install gym equipment in their boozers so members can hit the #xCbar-bell#xD in order to get around reopening restrictions.Marc Diaper, CEO at Gymbox, said it was #xCoutrageous#xD that pubs were opening before gyms #xCgiven the huge health benefits exercise#xD.Gymbox today said bosses are looking at letting its members visit the premises due to the “lack of clarity from the Government” - stock image:WHO says Covid- getting worse globallyThe COVID- pandemic is subsiding in Europe, but getting worse globally with the number of infections expected to reach  million next week and the number of deaths ,, the head of the World Health Organisation Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said.Speaking via video-conference with members of the European Parliament#xs health committee, Tedros said that once the pandemic was over, the world should notto its previous state, but build a #xCnew normal#xD that would be fairer, greener and help prevent climate change. testing facility in the car park of Chessington World of Adventures, as the spread of the coronavirus diseasecontinues, Chessington, Britain, March , . REUTERS Peter Nicholls" content"https:www.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES sb _THP_CHP_AI_AJPG.jpg"Medical staff at an NHS drive through coronavirus diseasetesting facility in the car park of Chessington World of Adventures:Walk in centres for testing to be set up for people without cars -  months after lockdown startedWalk-in centres for Covid- testing are to be set up to make it easier for people without cars to get tested for the virus. Six centres are being trialled in Newcastle, Rochdale, Leeds, Brent, Newham and Slough, with the latter described as a hybrid drive and walk through. The exact location of the centres has not been confirmed by officials but one is understood to be on a basketball court, and there have been reports they will spring up in empty shops and car parks. A source at the Department of Health and Social Caresaid officials were working on #xCwalk through testing sites in England for people without cars#xD. The source said that previously the push was to have testing sites out of the way so there were not #xChuge#xD numbers of potentially infected people travelling into the centre of towns. But they added that now incidence is lower, they can look at ways to safely provide testing #xCin the heart of communities#xD, in a way that is more easy and accessible to people. Downing Street said #xCthe right guidance and advice#xD would ensure the safety of walk-in coronavirus testing centres. The Prime Minister#xs official spokesman said: #xCWe have already been setting up mobile testing units to serve communities where needed. #xCWe want to ensure testing is available in places that are accessible and work for the public across the country.#xD :Decline in coronavirus cases has levelled off, ONS figures showThe decline in the number of people in England estimated to have Covid- has levelled off, new figures from the Office for National Statisticssuggest. The ONS said its estimates suggested the percentage testing positive has #xCclearly decreased over time#xD since the first measurement on April  and that #xCthis downward trend has now flattened#xD. An average of , people in private households had coronavirus at any given time between June  and June , according to new ONS estimates. This was the equivalent of .% of the population, or around one in , iniduals. The ONS, which publishes data on how many people at any one time are infected with Covid- based on swab results from households across the country, said: #xCModelling of the trend over time suggests that the decline in the number of people in England testing positive has levelled off in recent weeks. #xCNew modelling of the incidence rate trend over time suggests that incidence appears to have decreased between mid-May and early June, but has also since levelled off.#xD The figures look at community infections and do not include people staying in hospitals, care homes or other institutional settings. The ONS figures also suggest that between June  and June  there were an estimated four new Covid- infections for every , iniduals per week in private households in England - the equivalent of an estimated , new cases per week. This is higher than the estimate of , new cases per week for the period May  to June , but below the , per week estimated for May  to May . The ONS said that despite the latest figures suggesting the proportion of people with Covid- is slightly higher than in previous weeks , the uncertainty surrounding these estimates means #xCwe do not at this point have evidence that the current trend is anything other than flat#xD. The ONS added that, because of this uncertainty, #xCthe actual number of iniduals testing positive in the period June  to June  could be higher or lower than in the two previous periods#xD.:KEY EVENTBournemouth beach major incident declared as heatwave crowds branded appallingA major incident has been declared in Bournemouth after thousands of people packed the beach on the hottest day of the year.Thousands gathered on the beach as temperatures soared to C, with officials describing the scenes as #xCappalling#xD.Bournemouth Council Leader Vikki Slade said: #xCWe are absolutely appalled at the scenes witnessed on our beaches, particularly at Bournemouth and Sandbanks, in the last - hours. #xCThe irresponsible behaviour and actions of so many people is just shocking and our services are stretched to the absolute hilt trying to keep everyone safe. We have had no choice now but to declare a major incident and initiate an emergency response.#xDThe scenes comes just days after Prime Minister eased more lockdown measures, which will see pubs, bars and restaurants open from July .Click here for the full story.A major incident has been declared at Bournemouth beach:UK coronavirus death toll rises by  as daily cases creep back over ,The UK coronavirus death toll has risen by  as the number of daily cases have gone back above ,.The official death toll across all settings is now at , in the latest figures from the Department of Health today. This includes hospitals, care homes and the community.Including deaths from suspected cases of the disease, Britain#xs toll is over ,.There has been a further , new cases of coronavirus reported in the last  hours.Click here for the full story. :UK coronavirus hospital deaths up by  in lowest Thursday rise in lockdownThe UK#xs coronavirus hospital death toll has increased by  - the lowest rise on a Thursday in lockdown.England reported  new deaths, Wales had six, Scotland recorded two and Northern Ireland had zero amid calls for Boris Johnson and his ministers to prepare for a second wave of Covid- this winter. The daily increase of  is the lowest rise on a Thursday since  deaths were confirmed on March , five days before the UK went into lockdown.Read the full story here :Government says R rate still below The rate of spread of the coronavirus infection across the UK - the growth rate - remains at minus % to minus % per day. While the reproduction number, referred to as R, remains at . to .. The figures are unchanged from when they were published by the Government Office for Science and the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies on Friday.Earlier today, a spokesperson for the Prime Minister refused to saychanges to the lockdown would increase the R rate.:Rees-Mogg says pub-goers should enjoy a yard of alePub-goers should #xCgo back to drinking a yard of ale#xD to celebrate the reopening of pubs while adhering to revised social distancing guidance, Jacob Rees-Mogg said. Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Tuesday that businesses, including pubs, could reopen on July  subject to the latest social distancing requirements being observed. The two-metre social distance rule will be reduced to #xCone-metre plus#xD which works out at just over a yard.Tory MP Brendan Clarke-Smithasked what could be done to support the reopening of pubs.During business questions, Mr Rees-Mogg replied: #xCI think there#xs a very easy answer in pubs and that is people should go back to drinking a yard of ale. #xCBecausethey drink a yard of ale they will maintain social distancing while enjoying an extra large drink to celebrate the fact that they are back in the pub.#xDJacob Rees Mogg :Scotland death toll climbs by twoA total of , patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by two from , on Wednesday, Nicola Sturgeon said.Speaking at the Scottish Government#xs virtual coronavirus briefing, the First Minister said , people have tested positive for the virus in Scotland, up by five from , the previous day.This marks the second day in a row when new cases have been in single figures, the first time this has happened since March , pre-lockdown.There are  people in hospital with confirmed or suspected Covid-, a drop of .Of these patients,  were in intensive care, a fall of five.:Track and Trace reach , people in first three weeksDuring the first three weeks of Test and Trace, , people who had been identied as recent close contacts of people who had tested positive for Covid- were reached through the tracing system. This was % out of a total of , identied contacts. The remaining ,were identied as close contacts, but were not reached. Some of these people could not be reached because no communication details had been provided for them. :KEY EVENTEurope has increase in coronavirus cases for the first time in monthsEurope has reported an increase in coronavirus cases for the first time in months, according to the World Health Organisation .Hans Kluge, the regional director of WHO in Europe, said that there are still , new cases and  deaths every day.Some countries are experiencing cluster outbreaks after many managed to slow the spread of the virus and begin emerging from restrictive lockdowns.He said: #xCIn several countries across Europe, this risk has now become a reality #x  countries have seen increases in new cumulative cases over the past two weeks.#xCIn  of these countries, accelerated transmission has led to very signicant resurgence thatleft unchecked will push health systems to the brink once again in Europe.#xDRead more here.Deaths are declining in Europe but there are grim warnings of a second spike :Infectious diseases expert warns coronavirus cases could resurge as travel restrictions relaxInfectious diseases specialist Professor Paddy Mallon has told a coronavirus committee in Ireland he believes it is inevitable that the country will experience a resurgence of cases as it relaxes restrictions and permits more travel. He said: #xCWhat countries that Ireland is in the position of around the world have done with resurgence of cases - the majority of the resurgence is occurring because new infections are being introduced into the country either through people travelling into the country or through the movement of goods. #xCThe importance of containing infections at borders become higher as levels of community transmission drop off. So from the policy maker perspective,you want to maintain community transmission at a level that is minimum, it is important you have robust screening methods at the point of entry into the country. #xCWhat they are is open for debate - you could screen everyone or judge your screening and restrictions on the epidemiological of the outbreak of the country the person is coming from. Someone coming from New Zealand compared to someone from Texas - the risk assessments would be very dferent.#xDMore OnCoronavirus

story: NewsLockdown Brits use store cupboards and bathrooms to get peace and connect to WiFiA study of , people found Brit adults have had to improvise while working from home, using store cupboards and bathrooms to get peace and quiet and rearranging rooms to make them look nicer on video callsShareCommentsBySteve RichmondJoseph WilkesReporter:,  JUN NewsWorking from home can make it harder to get some peace and quiet " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. A study of , people found  per cent of those in London have even had to work from their bathroom to get online during the lockdown. The findings revealed how workers have had to improvise because of limits to the WiFi signal in their home with a third rearranging the room decor to make their background look better before going on a video call. And almost one in  have used virtual backgrounds on a video call to disguise where theyaposre working. The research was commissioned by EE to launch its new Smart WiFi home broadband service, designed to boost the WiFi coverage in every room of a customeraposs home. The study also revealed that one in three adults have rooms in their house that arenapost covered by their current WiFi router. Young adults were most likely to tamper with the router, with more than half of those aged between - years old moving it around in order to benefit their connection. However, only  per cent of those over  would bother trying to move the router to improve it. And --year olds were also the most likely to move items around in the background of their camera view to make their calls look nicer.

Plastic bags, bottles and picnic leftovers were seen scattered across the sand. Some of the rubbish also includes take-away bags and containers as well as cans. Other pictures show bins overflowing and tents set up on the beach.Thousands of people flocked to the seaside to enjoy the warm weather yesterday - the hottest day of the year so far.During the day, a major incident was declared by the local council in Bournemouth, urging sun-seekers to stay away from a packed beach. People were urged to act responsibly as the mercury reached highs of C yesterday. The council has slammed irresponsible people for gridlocking roads, dumping rubbish and parking illegally, as well as some people allegedly getting involved in fights. Traffic built up early on coast-bound roads and people travelled to Bournemouth from as far as Birmingham, BBC News reports.The council repeatedly asked people to stay away as the area became heavily congested. BCP Council issued  parking enforcement fines – the highest on record – and responded to many reports of cars parking and causing an obstruction. Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer, Professor Chris Whitty, saidpeople do not follow social distancing guidelines, there could be a risk of a second spike in coronavirus infections.Council leader Vikki Slade said they were absolutely appalled at the scenes witnessed on our beaches. She added: The irresponsible behaviour and actions of so many people is just shocking and our services are stretched to the absolute hilt trying to keep everyone safe.  We have had no choice now but to declare a major incident and initiate an emergency response. The scenes come just days after Prime Minister announced a major relaxation of the UK lockdown, with pubs, bars and restaurants set to reopen from July  and a new one-metre plus social distancing rule.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe re-opening of pubs next Saturday could unleash a couple of New Yearaposs Eves worth of drunk and disorderly behaviour, police have warned. Officers fear that strict social distancing rules will cause tensions to flare up as boozers gear up to open their doors for the first time in nearly four months. July  - or Super Saturday - will see pubs across England welcoming customers back with new safety measures as the coronavirus lockdown is gradually relaxed. These include no dancing, staying at least a metre apart from other customers, keeping voices down and ordering drinks through table service or mobile phone apps rather than heading to the bar.Punters will also be asked to leave their name at the door to help with contract tracing in the event of a coronavirus flare-up.For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here Amid fears that disputes could break out as staff try to ensure customers stick to the new rules, officers have argued that pubs should have been re-opened on a weekday.According to Steve Kent, the chair of South Yorkshireaposs Police Federation, the combination of hot, sunny weather and weekend crowds could create a perfect storm of disorderly behaviour.I think we’re going to have a couple of weeks of New Year’s Eves, he told the Independent. Meanwhile John Apter, chair of the Police Federation, which represents rank-and-file officers, has warned that Super Saturday will without doubt add to pressure on already-stretched police, paramedic and wider NHS services. He added that although the economy must get moving after months of lockdown, some were seeing July  as a countdown to party time. “There are worries about alcohol consumption leading to drunken and irresponsible behaviour, and there’s also the concern that people who can’t get into pubs because of restrictions that are still in place may cause conflict, he said. The public have shown support for their key workers during lockdown they can continue to give support by behaving sensibly now that the restrictions are easing.” Lockdown measures in England are set to be signicantly relaxed on July . Pubs, restaurants, hotels and hairdressers will be allowed to re-open and people will be able to gather in slightly larger groups.  For the first time, two households of any size will be able to gather inside - with social distancing. The two-metre rule will also be cut to one metre plus mitigations like face coverings, where two metres canapost be maintained. It comes as Bournemouth council was forced to declare a major incident today after thousands flocked to the seaside town. Overwhelmed police urged day-­trippers to stay away from beaches after the scenes of sunseekers flocking to resorts in the C heat sparked fears of a second coronavirus wave. Bournemouth Council leader Vikki Slade described scenes at the seafront as appalling after extra police were also drafted in amid reports of anti-social behaviour, fights, littering and abuse being hurled at council crews. The UKaposs coronavirus death toll increased by  today as the number of daily cases have gone back above ,. The official death toll across all settings is now at , in the latest figures from the Department of Health today. This includes hospitals, care homes and the community.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThunderstorms and lightning are set to cover the UK today after Thursday became the hottest day of the year. Storms are expected to bring heavy rain, lightning and hail - a big dference from yesterdayaposs weather. Two yellow weather warnings for thunderstorms are in place for much of the UK from Thursday to Saturday, warning of disruption due to flooding, lightning strikes, hail and wind. It comes after a heatwave hit the country earlier this week, with highs of C registered in parts of the UK. Yesterday was the hottest day recorded so far in . Under eased lockdown restrictions, Britons can enjoy the heat and visit parks, beaches and, when adhering to social distancing measures, see friends and family. Speaking about the reasons behind the hot spell, Met Office Chief Meteorologist, Dan Suri said: “We quite often see warm, southerly air from the continent bringing these high temperatures to the UK in summer, however this week, the air across the UK has arrived from the Atlantic. This Atlantic air will descend and warm up as it moves across the UK and this in combination with clear skies and strong late-June sunshine, we’re seeing temperatures rise.”  However this could change soon as temperatures are set to drop by about C in some areas of the country. Met Officer forecaster Alex Burkill told : Friday will be another hot day, but less hot than yesterday in many places.The Met Office has two thunderstorm warnings out which cover pretty much all of the UK because of a risk of torrential downpours - with hail, frequent lightning and heavy rain expected. Mr Burkill said: This marks the transition to something more changeable as we go into the weekend.  We are going to see spells of rain, stronger winds and temperatures are going to be less hot. The forecaster said some places will see temperatures dropping by C - remaining mainly in the low-s.  Today: Early showers and thunderstorms in western and southern parts extending north and east with some torrential downpours, lightning and a chance of hail. Sunshine between. Remaining very warm in the west but still hot and humid across much of England.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: We all need to respect social distancing so le can go back to normalAlthough most are behaving responsibility, the scenes at Bournemouth beach today show the risk of a second wave of Covid- is real - we should all respect the guidance so we canto normal leShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Having promised a zero tolerance approach to anti-Semitism he was as good as his word with his sacking of Rebecca Long-Bailey. Allies of the former Shadow Education Secretary feel she has been hard done by and the move could reignite isions in Labour. But the party leader should be applauded for taking a firm stand on an issue that has become a stain on his party’s reputation. It stands in contrast to Boris Johnson’s failure to dismiss Dominic Cummings or Robert Jenrick. Unlike Mr Starmer, the PM has been exposed as weak and unprincipled.

title: an inspiration to everyone tributes to the late dundee dance teacher doreen winter
story: A Dundee dance teacher who taught generations of city youngsters over more than six decades has died only weeks after being diagnosed with a terminal illness.Dozens of tributes have been paid to Doreen Winter of Dundee#s Dorwin School of Dancing, who died last Friday, aged .Doreen, who would have been  on July , taught dancing in Dundee for  years and was teaching up until  a week before lockdown.Her daughter, Linda, travelled from her home in Perth, Australia, five weeks ago to be with her mum and said she would be very sorely missed.#This is the end of an era. My dear mother has been a Dundee icon for many, many years,# she said.#She meant so many things to so many dferent people, all positive.#Mum just kept on dancing for as long as she could.#She was teaching dance right up until a week before lockdown. She was a real trooper. I am so proud of her. She was a strong and very giving lady and everyone she taught loved her.#She was a great role model for everyone she taught and I never saw her bitter or angry.#Doreen was diagnosed with a terminal illness seven weeks ago and was told only four days later that there was no treatment available.Linda said: #I had to get special permission to come home to be with her and she was absolutely delighted when I made it. I was so worried I wouldn#t be able to get here. I#m so glad I got to be with her at the end.#She was delighted when on June  the girls from the Dundee Sparkletts twirling group managed to get along to see her through the window.#She had a dferent story for each of the girls, that#s just what she was like. She was so uncomplaining about everything.#I am a nurse back home in Australia and I can honestly say she was the easiest patient I have ever had.#Doreen grew up in Downfield, the daughter of Tom Donaldson, who ran a bakery in Haldane.She began competitive dancing at a very young age and started teaching when she was .Doreen#s first love had been Highland dancing, which took her all over the world including Russia, America, China, Turkey and Italy as well as to other European cities.Linda said: #She was heavily involved in cultural dance exchanges. She was also a dance examiner and travelled widely with that.#As well as Highland dance, Doreen taught twirling, tap, line dancing and majorettes, and more recently was involved with the Dundee Sparkletts troupe.Linda added: #Mum was a member of the Gay Gordon#s Dancers, Downfield Musical Society  and her highland dancers, back in the late #s and early #s, were used on some of the Alexander Brothers shows and Ronnie Coburn shows across Scotland.#She also sang across Scotland on some of these shows.#Doreen also worked for a time as a silver service waitress in Dundee and in H Samuel the jeweller.As well as Linda, Doreen had two sons, Keith and Alan, four grandchildren and three great grandchildren.A spokesman for Dundee Sparkletts said: #She was an inspiration to everyone she met.#The girls at Dundee Sparkletts loved going to her class each week learning lots of techniques while having fun.#Not only was she their teacher, she treated every one of the girls as her own, building their confidence, encouraging them even when times were challenging and getting them all to believe in themselves.#Doreen#s funeral, which is private because of Covid- restrictions, is to be held next week.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. story: BT Sport host Darrell Currie supports ex-SPL chief Roger Mitchell’s recent assertion that the Scottish Premiership would be more attractive to broadcasters with both Dundee United and Dundee in it.The popular presenter would like to see all of the country’s major derbies played in the top flight and says such a set-up would appeal to TV bosses.The Tangerines – who lost boss Robbie Neilson to Hearts on Sunday – will start the   campaign in the Premiership on August  after winning the Championship.James McPake’s Dark Blues are set toto Championship action on October , with the SPFL last week confirming a --- structure for next season after reconstruction talks failed.Darrell, , told Tele Sport: “With BT down the years, we’ve always been big on the Dundee derby.“We certainly had a lot more Dundee derbies than Sky down the years and it was a game we always wanted to take. We’ve seen some unbelievable matches. They’ve given us some dramatic moments over the years.“It’s one of my favourite derbies I’ve ever worked on or watched. It’s an amazing game.“All of these games would be better in the top flight – Glasgow derbies, Edinburgh derbies, Dundee derbies, Highland derbies. I think we need them all.“Look at the league and the financial troubles some clubs are having. I know Gordonmade some strong comments and, for me, you absolutely need the sides that have a good history. You need them in the top flight.“I get that itshould be done in the fairest possible way. Right now, though, the game is crumbling and it’s on its knees.“We need our biggest clubs around and we need to make sure they emerge unscathed.”BT Sport’s live coverage of the SPFL ended when the   campaign was called and Darrell – involved in the broadcaster’s Bundesliga action – admits he is gutted at how events transpired.He said: “I think it’s sad I won’t get to work with the people I’ve worked with weekly in Scottish football but, equally, I’m under contract with BT and I’m fully expecting to stay on with them so you start to put your mind to what  you’re going to be working on right away.”Ex-Dundee star Nicky Riley is top of the class after big career change" title"#Ex-Dundee star Nicky Riley is top of the class after big career change# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp ex-dundee-star-nicky-riley-is-top-of-the-class-after-big-career-change embed # secretdmoPRlobSr" data-secret"dmoPRlobSr" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: tough ask awaits next dundee united manager says club legend hamish mcalpine
story: It’s one of the most attractive jobs in Scottish football but the next Dundee United manager will have his work cut out making a success of it.That’s the view of United legend Hamish McAlpine.The  Premier Division-winning goalkeeper was, like most, shocked by Robbie Neilson’s departure from Tannadice for Hearts on Sunday night.However, McAlpine insists the Tangerines can’t afford to feel sorry for themselves and must move on quickly.“It was a surprise,” the -year-old said.“I saw it late Sunday night on the news and I said to myself ‘what is that all about ’“There have been rumours left, right and centre about what went on but I wouldn’t want to speculate.“It does seem a strange one but he spent a lot of time in Edinburgh and Hearts were his first club so maybe his heart is there “It’s strange but never mind, United must move on.”McAlpine, who made  appearances for the Tangerines from -, thought Robbie would’ve stuck around for Premiership football with United as he now prepares for another assault on the Championship with the Jambos.He continued: “He did what he had to do. They failed in the play-offs last year, of course, but this year they got the right signing in Lawrence Shankland to win the title.“That made all the dference for them, scoring those goals, and they did get a wee bit steadier at the back.“Robbie would’ve known they’d have needed two or three players more for going up but I thought he’d still be there for the fight.“He’ll just have it all to do with Hearts again in that league.”As for who will lead the Terrors into the top flight, McAlpine says it’s anybody’s guess.Whether it’s Tommy Wright, Craig Levein or Lee McCulloch, the former goalie reckons they’ll have a job on their hands.LEE WILKIE: Craig Levein and Peter Houston could steady the ship for Dundee United" title"#LEE WILKIE: Craig Levein and Peter Houston could steady the ship for Dundee United# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-craig-levein-peter-houston-dundee-united embed # secretiNuOtGIDF" data-secret"iNuOtGIDF" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"However, McApline insists the club remain in a strong, attractive position for a new man coming in.“There’ll be plenty folk out of a job who’ll be desperate to take it,” he added.“With the crowds they can pull in they can have success. There’s a potential for , home fans at every game.“That’s a big attraction to a manager, having the big crowd behind them, because there’s not many places like that.“There’ll be a lot of CVs being sent through and, with Tommy being installed as favourite, I wouldn’t be surprised to see him end up at Tannadice.“I know they’d spoken to him before back in  but I’m not sure of the ins and outs of what they’re thinking now.“Anybody moving to United will be rubbing their hands because it’s an attractive job.“It will still be a tough ask but at least they’re in the right place in the Premiership.“It’s a struggle for half the teams in that league so they won’t be any worse off than most after a couple of signings.“They’ll need somebody up front to help Shankland, some pace and width and maybe another experienced defender.”He continued: “Somebody mentioned Craig Levein and Peter Houston to me but, obviously, with the new regime that’s come in at United, you just don’t know what they’d be thinking.“They were both at the club before, of course, and have that connection.“Craig’s been in and out of it with Hearts the last few years, had a spell as manager that didn’t work out and moved upstairs before it changed again.“Houstie has been coaching and scouting so he might fancy it but you never can tell.“Whoever they get has a hard job but at least they’re starting off in the right league.“The club will need to get their finger out to get somebody in, look over the squad and see where they need to strengthen and how much money they can spend.“That’s going to take time to get it sorted out so I think they’ll be wanting somebody in sooner rather than later.“Robbie has started them on a journey and what’s not to say a new manager won’t come in, have a look at them and push them on “He’ll like some of what he sees, might have dferent ideas about things but will it work  You just don’t know.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including
